Authors:
Laurene Levy, Guillermo Pimentel, L. M Carris, R. J. Meyer,
Lisa A. Castlebury
Title:
Internal Transcribed Spacer Sequence-Based Phylogeny and
Polymerase Chain Reaction-Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism
Differentiation of Tilletia walkeri and T. indica.
Abstract:
A polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length
polymorphism assay to distinguish Tilleita walkeri, a rye grass bunt
fungus that occurs in the southeastern United States and Oregon, from T.
indica, the Karnal bunt fungus, is described. The internal transcribed
spacer (ITS) region of the ribosomal DNA repeat unit was amplified and
sequenced for isolates of T. indica, T. walkeri, T. horrida, and a
number of other taxa in the genus Tilletia. A unique restriction digest
site in the ITS1 region of T. walkeri was identified that distinguishes
it from the other taxa in the genus. Phylogenetic analysis of the taxa
based on ITS sequence data revealed a close relationship between T.
indica and T. walkeri, but more distant relationships between these two
species and other morphologically similar taxa.
